raw_text:
Indy buys into India paper
 
 Irish publishing group Independent News & Media is buying up a 26% stake in Indian newspaper company Jagran in a deal worth 25m euros ($34.1m).
 
 Jagran publishes India's top-selling daily newspaper, the Hindi-language Dainik Jagran, which has been in circulation for 62 years. News of the deal came as the group announced that its results would meet market forecasts. The company reported strong revenue growth across all its major markets.
 
 Group advertising revenues were up over 10% year-on-year, the group said, with overall circulation revenues are expected to increase almost 10% year-on-year. This was helped by the positive impact of "compact" newspaper editions in Ireland and the UK, it said. "2004 has proven to be an important year for Independent News & Media," said chief executive Sir Anthony O'Reilly. "Our simple aim at Independent is to be the low cost producer in every region in which we operate. I am confident that we will show a meaningful increase in earnings for 2005."
 
 Meanwhile, the group made no comment about the future of the Independent newspaper despite recent speculation that Sir Anthony had held talks with potential buyers over a stake in the daily publication. He has consistently denied suggestions that the Independent and the Independent on Sunday are up for sale. Buy it is understood that the recent success of the smaller edition of the Independent, which has pushed circulation up by 20% to 260,000, has prompted interest from industry rivals, with Daily Mail & General Trust tipped as the most likely suitor. The loss-making newspaper is not expected to reach break-even until 2006.
llama3.2:1b: Irish publishing group Independent News & Media buys a stake in Indian newspaper Jagran for 25m euros ($34.1m).
Jagran publishes India's top-selling daily, Dainik Jagran, which has been in circulation since 1962.
The company reported strong revenue growth across its markets, with over a 10% year-on-year increase in advertising and overall circulation revenues.
The deal is seen as part of Independent News & Media's goal to be the low-cost producer in every region where it operates.
llama3.2:3b: Independent News & Media buys 26% stake in Indian newspaper company Jagran for $34.1m.
Jagran publishes India's top-selling daily newspaper, Dainik Jagran, which has been in circulation for 62 years.
The deal comes as the group reports strong revenue growth across its major markets, with a 10% increase in group advertising revenues and a expected 10% year-on-year increase in circulation revenues.
gemma2:2b: Independent News & Media (INM) purchased a 26% stake in Indian newspaper company Jagran for €25 million.
INM reported strong revenue growth and anticipates further increase in circulation revenues.
While the future of the Independent newspaper remains unclear, speculation suggests it might be sold to Daily Mail & General Trust.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Independent News & Media buys a stake in India's Jagran newspaper for €34.1 million.
The company is reporting strong revenue growth across all markets and positive impact of "compact" newspaper editions in Ireland and the UK, which could boost earnings for 2005.
However, Sir Anthony O'Reilly declined to comment on the future of Independent, saying that he was confident that it would show a meaningful increase in earnings.
The smaller edition of the independent paper is expected to reach break-even by the end of 2006.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Independent News & Media buys a 26% stake in Indian newspaper company Jagran for €25 million.
The deal follows strong revenue growth across markets and positive impact of compact edition.
CEO mentions meeting target earnings increase for 2005.
Meanwhile, Independent's smaller edition reportedly attracts rival interest.
qwen2.5:3b: Irish publishing group Independent News & Media buys a 26% stake in Indian company Jagran for €25m.
Jagran publishes India's top-selling daily, Dainik Jagran.
IN&M’s results met forecasts and saw strong year-over-year revenue growth across markets.
CEO Sir Anthony O'Reilly noted 2004 as an important year with plans to increase earnings in 2005.
Despite speculation about selling the Independent newspaper, IN&M has not commented.

Interest from industry rivals, including Daily Mail & General Trust, suggests a potential acquisition of the smaller Independent edition, which saw circulation rise by 20% to 260,000 and is expected to break even in 2006.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Indentee bought a 26% stake in Jagran newspaper (worth 25m euros) as part of a strategic purchase.
The group reported strong growth in revenue and circulation revenues, primarily driven by "compact" newspapers.
Independent's CEO, Sir Anthony O'Reilly, emphasized that 2004 was a key year for them, aiming to maintain low costs across regions and expect earnings growth in 2005.
However, the newspaper is not expected to break even until 2006.
tinyllama:1.1b: Indian publishing group Independent News & Media (IN&M) has acquired a 26% stake in India's leading daily newspaper, Jagran, for 25 million euros ($34.1 million).
This deal includes acquiring a minority stake in the top-selling newspaper Dainik Jagran.
The company also reported strong growth across all its major market areas during fiscal year 2004, with revenues up over 10% year-on-year.
Group advertising revenues were also up almost 10%, as circulation revenues are expected to increase almost 10% by the end of fiscal year 2005.

IN&M's simple aim at its core operation is to be a low-cost producer in every region where it operates, and the company made no comment about future plans for the Independent newspaper despite speculation that Sir Anthony O'Reilly, group chief executive, has held discussions with potential buyers over a stake.
Despite recent industry rumors, IN&M has stated its intention to keep both the Daily Mail & General Trust (DMGT) and the Independent titles on their current management.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In a recent announcement, Independent News & Media (INM) has acquired a 26% stake in India's largest daily newspaper company Jagran for €34.1 million ($46.7 million).
This acquisition is part of the INM's strategy to expand its presence across multiple regions and strengthen its position as an affordable low-cost publisher.
In 2004, INM aimed to show a meaningful increase in earnings for 2005, but it has not commented on this aspect.
It is also unknown whether the acquisition of Jagran's stake will lead to any changes in the management team or the future direction of operations for INM.
phi:2.7b: Irish publishing group Independent News & Media purchased a 26% stake in Indian newspaper company Jagran for 25m euros.
Jagran publishes Dainik Jagran, India's top-selling daily newspaper with 62 years of circulation.
Group advertising revenues were up over 10%, and the positive impact of compact editions helped overall revenue growth.
Despite speculation that Sir Anthony O'Reilly had held talks to buy Independent, the group made no comment on future plans for the Daily Mail & General Trust newspaper.
orca-mini:3b: Irish publishing group Independent News & Media is buying a 26% stake in Indian newspaper company Jagran for €34.1 million.
The deal includes the Hindi-language Dainik Jagran daily newspaper, which has been in circulation for 62 years and generates strong advertising revenues.
Group advertising revenues were up over 10%, while circulation revenues are expected to increase by almost 10%.
Sir Anthony O'Reilly, the group's CEO, aims to increase earnings for the company, with a focus on being the low-cost producer in every region they operate.

While Sir Anthony has consistently denied rumors about selling the Independent newspaper, he is understood to have interest from industry rivals, with Daily Mail & General Trust predicted as the most likely suitor.
The daily newspaper is not expected to reach break-even until 2006.
hermes3:3b: Indy buys 26% stake in Indian newspaper company Jagran (Hindi-daily Dainik Jagran), $34m deal.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Irish publishing group Independent News & Media acquires a 26% stake in Indian newspaper company Jagran for €25m ($34.1m).
This deal comes as the company reports strong revenue growth, with overall circulation revenues expected to increase almost 10% year-on-year due to compact newspaper editions in Ireland and the UK.
There is no comment on the future of the Independent newspaper, but industry rivals are said to be interested, particularly Daily Mail & General Trust.

Jagran publishes India's top-selling daily, Dainik Jagran.
The deal was announced alongside strong financial results, with group advertising revenues up over 10% year-on-year and circulation revenues expected to rise nearly 10%.
CEO Sir Anthony O'Reilly emphasized the company's goal of being a low-cost producer and projected earnings growth for 2005.
Meanwhile, speculation continues about the future of the Independent newspaper, though O'Reilly denies it is for sale.
The success of its smaller edition has increased circulation by 20%, attracting industry interest, with Daily Mail & General Trust seen as a potential buyer.
The newspaper is not expected to break even until 2006.
stablelm2:1.6b: Irish publishing group Independent News & Media acquired a 15% stake in Indian newspaper company Jagran for €1.1m ($1.4m), making it India's top-selling daily newspaper.
The acquisition comes as the firm announced its results will meet market forecasts, with strong revenue growth across all major markets.
Group advertising revenues increased by over 20% YoY while overall circulation revenues are expected to rise almost 20% YoY due to positive effects of compact newspaper editions in Ireland and UK.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Irish publishing giant Independent News & Media acquired a 26% stake in Indian newspaper Jagran for 25 million euros, focusing on Dainik Jagran, India's top Hindi-language daily with 62 years of history.
The deal coincided with the company reporting strong revenue growth across major markets, including a 10% year-on-year increase in advertising and an almost 10% rise in circulation.
CEO Sir Anthony O'Reilly expressed confidence in meeting earnings targets for 2005, emphasizing the group's aim to be a low-cost producer.

Despite speculation about potential buyers for the Independent newspaper (which has seen a 20% circulation boost), no official comment was made on the future of the publication, amidst rumors that Daily Mail & General Trust might be interested due to its smaller edition's success.
The Independent is anticipated to reach profitability only in 2006.
